positive.review:
Clair Obscur feels like one of those games that shouldn’t exist, but somehow does because a bunch of passionate weirdos decided “yeah, why not?”

The dev story alone is wild:
A French dude who speedruns Sekiro gets tired of his job at Ubisoft and just… quits to make his dream game. He calls his old university buddy, who ends up becoming the lead tech. He finds a musician on SoundCloud who makes the entire OST. He finds a girl on Reddit who agrees to voice the demo for free—and she eventually becomes the lead writer.

Then they hire like thirty fresh grads who are all in over their heads but clearly giving it everything they’ve got. And member number thirty-three? A dog. Literally credited as the Happiness Manager in the end credits.
And the crazy part is: the game actually turned out great. Stylish, unique, full of heart—exactly the kind of thing you get when people make something because they want to, not because some exec told them to.

Clair Obscure is a win for gamers and a big, beautiful middle finger to AAA companies that fill their games with garbage and micro transactions.

If this doesn't win GOTY I will shove 33 esquie plushies up my *** because there is no way on the painter's green earth it ain't. Absolutely criminal that this got snubbed at the grammys when the OST literally went dimdim da dada and sat at the top of the charts for weeks, absolute cinema

My god, this might be one of the best games I've ever played. It's clear Lorien and the team poured their souls into this masterpiece.

The artwork is just... fabulous. Perfect amount of fantasy. During cutscenes, during combat, you're really never left feeling like something was missing.

Turn-based combat is also really well done here. QTEs aren't forgiving at first, but you get the hang of it. Parry windows are extremely short, but man is it ever satisfying when you get it right. Equipment choice also really matters. Not just cuz of the stat increases, but also because of the unique benefits they give in combat. 

Every time I got into a new area, new boss, new enemies, a new track played. And man, were those tracks great to hear. In fact, I still listen to some of the tracks outside the game. They're just so good.

Heavily recommend this game, for any person that loves music, loves art, loves stories, loves turn-based combat, loves QTEs. loves RPGs. Worth it at full price, and even more so at a discount. A rare occasion for our sad gaming industry.

I think E33 is geniunely a good contender for GOTY and I get why its so critically acclaimed but I also get why some people dislike it as the mileage someone will get from it heavily depends on how much one resonates with the themes and the story in it, if for any reason someone doesn't resonate with the themes or dislikes them, they will most likely dislike the game overall. Thanks to how universal those themes are tho, vast majority of people will love the story and things it offers, it brought me to tears and I think it is a really good game. 

The only two things I geniunely disliked about the game were the choice of an engine that I think greatly fucked with the incredible art direction and the gameplay stinks for the most part, I will never get behind parry/dodge system.

Is the game good? Yes. Is it some kind of a flawless masterpiece as some people hype it to be? No, it isn’t. In fact, if there was a neutral review - I would make it, because even while writing this review I am not entirely sure if I should make it a positive or a negative one. Now, let’s get a bit into the details.

[h1] THE GOOD[/h1]
[list]
    [*] Music/sound. If I had to pick the best part of this game - it would be music. It is insanely good, to the point where I stopped at some locations just to enjoy the soundtrack. And it is also masterfully used to amplify plot/gameplay moments and create the mood for the events  you are going through. Pure 10/10, will listen again.
    [*] World. It is interesting and well-made. It has enough weirdness to be interesting to explore and enough things to reward you with for that exploration, even though gameplay wise it is just a bunch of corridors.
    [*] Characters. Unlike so many other games, characters here are neither blank self-inserts nor some kind of one-dimensional cardboard cutouts, they all have personality and depth that makes them interesting to follow.
    [*] Plot. I will not call it great, but as a journey for our party it feels interesting, with a lot at stake and seemingly impossible challenges to overcome.
[/list]

[h1] THE BAD[/h1]
[list]
    [*] Platforming. I don’t really understand why you would include any platforming into a game that doesn’t have snappy movement and where characters sometimes switch to tank controls. I understand even less what kind of a developer would wake up and say “Hey, I know what we need in our story-rich RPG - streamer rage games!”. Not only those parts are absolute cancer to play through, but they also show how unreliable movement and physics in the game are - you constantly slide from what seems to be flat surfaces, fail to grab a ledge, get stuck on smallest things - it simply feels infuriating and out of place in this game.
    [*] Pacing. It is simply weird. Act one is great, act two starts slowing down, as some of your attacks hit damage cap, while your enemies continue to increase their HP. Act three is a complete mess, as you are given a choice: either you go for the final fight, that is available from the start, and miss a lot of plot related information and a bunch of interesting content, or you go for said content and arrive at final boss so overpowered that this whole epic last fight loses any and all weight and impact, as you are just mopping up everyone with one shot AOE attacks.
    [*] Lack of QOL features. You meet the enemy that you already fought, but forgot what elemental weaknesses it has? No journal, no markings in status bar, the only place to get this information is fan wiki. You want to change your perks? The menu has no presets, no search, no customisable filters - so every time the process becomes tedious and time-consuming.
    [*] Combat. Considering that most of the gameplay time you will spend in combat - this is the thing that makes or breaks the game for you. And while many people were fine with it, I see too many problems with the system and it simply doesn’t work for me. While turn-based RPG requires you to exploit elemental weaknesses, prepare for combat and level up appropriately, the realtime system allows you to ignore everything I just mentioned by having good reaction - you can just dodge/parry almost any attack without paying attention to elements and levels. And if you go from the opposite direction of realtime action - there is way too much waiting for all of the animations to play. Sure, they are cool, but they are cool for the first 10 fights with this monster - not for 100s of times you are going to fight it afterwards. I also found the attack patterns on enemies erratic and confusing - not only the attack animation goes for far too long, but it also has several feints and weird delays, which makes fighting an enemy for the first time extremely frustrating and basically impossible to win (at later stages even with good levels you will still be oneshotted by almost anyone). And just to top it all off - at the end you will be able to get several builds that do millions of damage killing almost all enemies apart from some bosses in one hit - completely negating both the depth of turn-based element and required reaction as you don’t even let the enemy attack. And the fact that I enjoyed those OP builds (because they allowed me to get to the ending faster while engaging in combat less) should tell you enough about how much I hated the combat system.
[/list]

Overall: I did enjoy the game. However I enjoyed it in spite of the horrible combat system - the story/world/characters carried the game for me. So while I can recommend playing the game, I am also warning you not to expect much from the combat system - as it is really a coin flip whether you like it or not. And don’t expect it to be some kind of a “once in a millenia game” as so many people hype it to be, as honestly, while it is good - it is not THAT good.

Clair Obscure: Expedition 33 - симфония света и тьмы, написанная дрожащей рукой надежды.

Невозможно передать словами, насколько глубоко "Clair Obscure: Expedition 33" проникла в моё сердце. Это не просто игра - это поэма в движении, написанная огнём заката и пеплом утра. Она не стремится быть идеальной - она хочет быть настоящей. И в этом её неповторимая сила.

Каждый элемент здесь - не просто часть формулы успеха, а отдельная нота в великой симфонии, где:
* Музыка не сопровождает действие - она становится самим действием. Она дышит, рвётся из груди, замирает в паузах между выстрелами и шёпотом прощаний. Она - душа мира, который вы исследуете.
* Визуальная часть - это живопись, ожившая в потоках пикселей и акварельных теней. Каждая локация будто вырвана из сна поэта-мизантропа, где красота и ужас идут рука об руку.
* Сюжет - тонкая, почти хрупкая ткань, сотканная из вопросов, а не ответов. Он не диктует - он предлагает задуматься, вспомнить, почувствовать. Он болезненно честен, особенно когда говорит о потерях, детстве и цене спасения мира, который, возможно, уже не хочет быть спасённым.
* Атмосфера здесь - почти физическое ощущение: как будто воздух в игре можно потрогать, как будто ветер несёт с собой шёпоты прошлого.
* Геймплей, несмотря на свою тактическую основу, удивительно элегантен. Он не отвлекает - он усиливает. Каждое решение в бою ощущается как моральный выбор, даже если речь идёт просто о перезарядке умений при атаках.
* Персонажи - не герои и не антагонисты, а живые люди с трещинами в душах, с надеждами, которые они прячут под шутками и молчанием. Их истории хочется слушать наизусть, перечитывать, как любимые стихи.
* Мир - это отдельный персонаж. Он дышит, страдает, иногда улыбается сквозь руины. Он не просто фон - он свидетель.

Однако, в этой почти идеальной картине есть одна хрупкая нота предостережения - третий акт. Именно здесь стоит быть особенно внимательным. Если вы решите полностью пройти все побочные задания, собрать каждое достижение и прокачать героев до предела -  финальные сражения, задуманные как эмоциональный катарсис, превратятся в техническую формальность. Боссы, над которыми команда, вероятно, работала с трепетом и драматургией, будут падать за секунды, не успев произнести последнее слово. Это не их вина - это трагедия выбора игрока.

Поэтому мой совет - и он родился из собственного горького опыта: в третьем акте идите прямо к финалу. Не сбавляйте темп. Позвольте себе прожить кульминацию в том ритме, в котором её задумали создатели. Плачьте, если захочется. Смотрите титры до конца - даже если за ними скрывается не надежда, а вопрос. А уже потом, вооружившись платиной как целью и спокойствием как союзником, загрузите последнее сохранение и отправляйтесь собирать то, что осталось за кадром. Либо перед финалом выполните побочные задания своей группы и тогда уже идите на финальный рамс.

"Clair Obscure: Expedition 33" - не просто одна из лучших игр года. Это редкий пример того, как видеоигра может стать произведением искусства, не жертвуя при этом своей игровой сутью. Она не просит вас поверить в чудо - она даёт вам возможность его почувствовать. Даже если это чудо будет больным, неоднозначным и оставит после себя вопрос без ответа.

И в этом её величайшая победа.
Looks like a tech demo, plays like a proper game. Its existence is almost surreal.

An absolute masterpiece. 

No game comes even close to this one, nothing remotely good has been released in over a decade of gaming. The game looks beautiful, it plays as good if not better (reminds of the old good final fantasy games aka 7 and 10). There is no slop in the game, not one bit, the story is great which is being told with great voice acting through well written dialogue. Build variety sheer endless via an amazing ingame system in order to change and experiment/tinker. 

The game puts all AAA developers to shame, they don't need to brag with how many people worked on the game (i think at the end something along of 50) but let the quality speak for itself.

To top it all of the soundtrack just slams the pedal down and doesn't stop at any point. When this game wins GOTY, the OST will be a big part of it. Pure beauty, everybody should enjoy the experience this game delivers. This game blurs the lines between art/game, a testament to why I fell in love with video games so many years ago. 

This game deserves all the praise, hype, glaze it got and more. It deserves game of the decade, play it blind, play it now and do not regret waiting like me.

Merci beaucoup.

[h1]Games like Expedition 33 is the reason why I love video games[/h1]
[h2]
[/h2]
Expedition 33 probably one of the games that I will never forget and wish to experience again for the first time.
[h2]
[/h2]
[h2]The Gameplay & Story   [/h2]
Every time I play this game, there was never a moment that felt boring and repetitive. From start to finish, this game is so good and fun to the point where I wish it never ended. The gameplay is probably one of the best Turn-Based combat I have ever played. This game allows you to react on almost, if not, all enemy attacks. You can parry, dodge, jump, and counter all of the enemy attacks in the game. So basically if you have mastered these mechanics, you can probably finish the game without dying or even taking any damage. Also, the build variety for the characters is so diverse that you can have different kinds of builds. There are also a lot of enemy variations where up until the end of the story you encounter new type of enemies. The story is so unique and well written, where it doesn't straight up tell you everything that is happening and let's you piece the story all together. The story pacing is an enjoyable slow burn that always keeps you invested until the end.
[h3]
[/h3]
[h2]The Soundtrack & Graphics[/h2]
The soundtrack is probably one of my favorite aspects of this game. There are so many that was created for this game and all of them were used perfectly on the game's story and gameplay. When I open up my game, I sometimes just stay on the title screen just to listen. The soundtrack on this game is so good that I don't there are any more room for improvement. It simply is just peak. I can also confidently say the same with the graphics, everything in this game looks so beautiful, from scenery, character and enemy designs, and overall vibe of the world. Everything is an eye candy. I love it.
[h3]
[/h3]
[h2]A Few Small Complaints[/h2]
There are very little things that I don't like about the game. First of all, the movement of the characters could get some improvement, although sometimes movement can feel a little jank, it does not ruin the experience of the gameplay and story even for a little bit. As the game is graphically demanding, there are only few graphics settings you can tweak, which lower-end PCs won’t benefit much. 
[h3]
[/h3]
[h2]My Overall Thoughts[/h2]
Expedition 33 is my Game of the Year. It does not fall short on everything that it delivered. Be it from gameplay, story, and soundtrack. This game is so good that there are only a few complaints that I can give, and even those, does not break the game's immersion. That's how good this game is. 
[h2]
[/h2]
I highly recommend Expedition 33 to anyone to try this game. It deserves EVEN more praise from what it's getting right now.
[h2]
[/h2]
[h3][i]"For those who come after."[/i][/h3]

It seems like the time has come to write a review for Game of the Year.

I've been waiting for this year to come to an end, for all the big new releases to die down, for me to decide for myself which game is the best this year, after evaluating everything I was interested in.

And you know, I could have been writing this review as early as April 24, 2025 – nothing has changed since then. This game didn't win Game of the Year – it won the Game of the Year category itself. No one could come close to it, or even come close to its level. This is a competition without intrigue, without losers, only a winner.

Long live Clair Obscur: Expedition 33.

I don't know how to continue writing this review without all sorts of spoilers for those who come after.

I've never seen a story as gripping, heart-stirring, interesting, and incredible as this one. Jennifer Svedberg-Yen has captivated me. She's created a masterpiece. The world, the lore, the characters, their interactions, the backstory, the development, the relationships, the experiences—all of this will leave you captivated. Imagine me saying this when the equally wonderful RDR2 already exists, where the people at Rockstar Games, with endless money and decades of experience, worked hard on the story. I don't want to downplay the value of that story, but imagine what had to happen for me to dare say something like that, where the author is writing a game story for the first time in his life, and yet he stands on par with Dan Houser. That's talent.

And I haven't even mentioned the level design and the music yet. I don't know what to say. It's simply priceless. It can't be conveyed; you just have to experience it yourself. And while you don't have to buy the game to listen to the music, its full potential will only be realized when you listen to it while your heart leaps out of your chest from the action on screen. I just want to remind you that Lorien Testard was an unknown musician on SoundCloud.

Right now, as I'm writing this review, listening to the game's soundtrack, the hair on my arms is standing on end and goosebumps the size of dinosaurs are running down my spine.

It's a masterpiece. I won't tire of repeating it. If I were incredibly rich, I'd buy it for everyone. Moreover, it's a perfect example of how games should be made. You don't need huge studios and thousands of people, you don't need billions in budgets. You need a team that's ready to make games, that wants to make games, and that loves games. You need Sandfall Interactive, you don't need Yves Guillemot.

If you're having doubts about whether to pick up the game (it's a sin to have doubts), you're afraid of the combat, you don't like it, then definitely pick it up. There's nothing to regret. The story, the music, the world, the gameplay, the build structure—everything is wonderful here (except for the "only up" levels; let's be honest, but no one is forcing you to play them). The ones who will regret it are those who haven't played it. I'd never played a game like this before or since, and I have no experience with combat like this, so that scared me too. I picked up the controller and forgot everything.

For those who come after!

To be honest, I don’t even know what to write. This game is so good that nothing really fits into words. One thing I can say for sure is that it brought my inspiration back, and that’s worth something.

At first, I planned to buy the PS5 physical version at release to enjoy the game on a big TV, but it stayed out of stock for ages, so I eventually gave up.
After months, a friend visited me and we talked about Clair Obscur Expedition 33. I finally decided to buy the game on Steam with a discount and see for myself: And woah, I really should have played earlier. Expedition 33 is mind-blowing and now I get why the reviews are so dithyrambic!

Finished in about 50 hours, I still have many zones to explore and bosses to defeat!

The visuals are impressive and the art direction is perfect, the studio managed to create an amazing world filled with emotions. As for the story, I won’t say anything to avoid spoilers, but I loved the whole experience and it’s the kind of adventure you really have to live yourselves. The characters elevate the whole narrative.

The OST is a delicacy for the ears and it’s crazy that the composer wasn’t known before. You can change the difficulty whenever you want so perfect for any players.
Clair Obscur Expedition 33 borrows some mechanics from souls-like games and it works really well.

Turn-per-turn usually isn’t my cup of tea but Clair Obscur Expedition 33 makes it genuinely interesting : thanks to the parry and dodge mechanics. And I’ve got to say, I’m a fanboy of parry-mechanic games!

Just one small bad thing: you can’t rebind the controller, so if you’re used to parrying with LB, switching to RB isn’t possible. Good thing there’s a mod that fixes this.

I do recommend Clair Obscur Expedition 33! You won’t be disappointed. My 2025 GOTY.
An amazing story in a beautiful, original setting. Gorgeous graphics, stellar soundtrack (that I still listen to). A memorable game that everyone that enjoys RPGs should try.

Beautiful game, even more beatiful sound track. Unique gameplay and features that make this a truly once in a lifetime experience. Would recommend even if you're not used to this genre (I'm not either). Definetely deserves all the love it gets.

[h1][i]"When one falls, we continue."[/i][/h1]

This review is going to sound like it was written by a kid who just finished their very first video game. Which is funny, because it's exactly the opposite. After being a gamer for almost 40 years, I rarely get seriously impressed by a game. If anything, they often feel like a chore, just because of the "been there, done that" effect. But this? This is... Wow. Or should I say "owowow?"

Anyway, our story begins with Ubisoft, the company known for its greed and copy/pasted games. And our hero, Guillaume Broche, grew tired of that. He wanted creativity, not just a paycheck. He left. And he wasn't alone. Another Ubisoft employee, Tom Guillermin, left with him, and since Tom knew Unreal Engine, they started fooling around with it. Things started to take form, and we got an early draft called Sandfall (originally, the game was supposed to revolve around time). But clearly, they needed more people, so... they wrote on Reddit (that was the scale, a bloody Reddit post). They looked for voice actors, but instead, they found their lead writer—Jennifer Svedberg-Yen. And she...

OK, it's hard to describe the story of the game without spoiling it (actually, the one who included certain scenes in the trailer is a criminal). Again, with too many games behind me, I'm rarely excited about stories in video games. Heck, I'm one of those people who hated Last of Us, just because of all the "Will you shut up already? I want to shoot something!" Clair Obscur? Blew me away. Think MYST. Think Cornelia Funke's Inkheart novels, but also think something absolutely unique and beautiful. And also sad. Very sad. Like Cyberpunk 2077 (you can say a lot of things about that game, but it had some really good characters, and its story made a lot of impact because of how things were never fair), Clair Obscur pays so much attention to characters (without making things boring) that it's literally impossible not to care. And when you begin caring? The game will break your freakin' heart. Welcome to Clair Obscur, guys. A world of infinite sadness. Sadness so thick you can feel it with your skin. Which is... Shocking. Not because it's good (it is, though; both the story and atmosphere here are absolutely amazing), but because... Jennifer never wrote for video games. Heck, her previous job didn't even involve writing! Yet here we are. One of the most beautiful stories I've seen in ages.

And you know what? It wasn't just Jennifer. Sandfall (even though the game wasn't about time anymore, Guillaume and Tom kept the name and gave it to the company they co-founded) hired another person with no experience—Lorien Testard. Who's Lorien? Well, he's a guitar teacher who worked on music for fun and posted tracks on SoundCloud. That's it. That's our guy behind the music. Means we've got a cute, yet simple soundtrack, right? Wrong. No, seriously, you couldn't be more wrong. With the help of soprano singer Alice Duport-Percier, Lorien created one of the most beautiful soundtracks I've heard in my entire life. It's not a paid review, but honestly, it's one of those cases when you simply must buy yourself a soundtrack. It's one of a kind, and it's impossible to forget it. You [i]will[/i] keep listening to it long after you finish the game.

Finally, a couple of words about visuals. And it's yet another name that changed the project's look entirely. Originally, in its times as Sandfall, Clair Obscur was a Victorian steampunk. Hence, hiring Nicholas Maxson-Francombe, an illustrator known for such stuff, was logical. I mean, he's another one with no experience with video games whatsoever, but it still made sense. The thing is though, while looking at some random pictures he made, Guillaume understood that those are much more beautiful than what the team had in mind originally. Nicholas for the game's visuals is what Jennifer is for the story. It's hard to describe what he did specifically, but... let's just say he somehow captured a certain kind of [i]magic[/i] in his design. Thanks to him, the game has its own face, its own signature design. Unique and instantly recognizable.

But OK, for a person who believes that gameplay is the most important part, I talked too much about story, music, and visuals. What about the gameplay? Well, what we have here is JRPG. And yes, this game is not Japanese. It's French. Very French. A French aesthetic is everywhere. It's so French that, exactly like I recommend playing Japanese RPGs with the Japanese voices, I recommend playing this one with the French ones. And yes, thanks to the publisher and other financial incomes, English voices here come with the Hollywood cast, but still, I can't imagine this game without the French cast (since you can simply switch to it in options, it looks like it was suggested by the devs too). Yet it's JRPG. Because somehow JRPG became a genre's name, and JRPGs that were not made in Japan have been a thing for quite some time (Septerra Core anyone?).

And you know what? It's yet another cool thing about this game. Let's just admit it, JRPGs are struggling now. Lots of them feel exactly the same (like those games from the Idea Factory, for example), while major franchises like Final Fantasy are going through one heck of an identity crisis. Personally, I used to love those up until PS2 times, where the gameplay changed so much that the games became something entirely different. Clair Obscur? In a way, it's what Final Fantasy wants to be but fails. It's also important to remember another Square-Enix title – The Legend of Dragoon. Remember how that game used a smart workaround to make turn-based battles more dynamic? Clair Obscur does the same. And it goes all the way into that direction. Despite being turn-based, it wants you to dodge, parry, and even jump during the battles. Which makes it feel almost real-time at times. And it feels... Awesome.

No, seriously. The battles here feel almost like something from the rhythm games. Remember good ol' Patapon? That's the stuff. When it's about those big bosses, you either pon-pon-patapon their attacks or die. And it's not just a coincidence, it's by design. On many occasions, the characters will compare battles to dances. Like everything else in this game, battles are bloody art. And so is the leveling mechanics.

Personally, I don't like overly complicated mechanics. Sitting on my butt and doing micromanagement for hours instead of exploring and fighting? Not really my thing. Clair Obscur? It can pleasure both people like me [i]and[/i] the micromanagement crowd. Long story short, things revolve around some items called "pictos." Those are the things you can equip on your characters for certain effects (like Materia in Final Fantasy). What's interesting here is that those chain. Here's an example: There's that ultimate boss who can and will one-hit-kill you. What can you do about it? Well, you can equip certain pictos. One will instantly resurrect you and give you a second chance, another gives you some buff upon being resurrected, and the third one will give the boss a debuff. Do pictos right and you'll be able to one-hit-kill every single enemy in this game, including that ultimate boss. Which is extremely satisfying.

And again, it was intentional. Clair Obscur's developers weren't just making a game. They were making a game they wanted to play for themselves. You can feel it everywhere. In how very special and personal the story is, in how beautiful the music is... Even the gameplay is full of some little touches it's hard not to praise. For example, my biggest problem with the genre is that battle animations are very long and the UI is too bulky. Sandfall guys? They felt the same. Thanks to which battles, despite being extremely spectacular, are also pretty fast-paced. So yeah. What we have here is not just GOTY, it's the best game I've played in, like, a decade. You either love Clair Obscur or you just didn't play it yet. It's simple like that.

Misunderstood artist gets rejected from art school and causes mass genocide on the human race.
10/10 would recommend

Strengths

Artistic design and atmosphere: The light-and-shadow theme, spatial designs, and visuals are truly captivating.

Music and audio: Testard's compositions and the voice cast deepen the gaming experience.

Combat system: Both strategic and dynamic, distinct from classic turn-based RPGs yet maintaining a familiar feel.

Story and characters: Emotionally rich and thematically mature, successfully exploring themes such as death, loss, and hope.

Community and critic support: High scores on Metacritic and very positive player ratings, the game is also a commercial success.

Developer commitment: Patch support, balance adjustments, and gameplay improvements demonstrate the developer's commitment to the player community.



Who's It For?

RPG lovers: If you particularly enjoy classic turn-based RPGs, but are also looking for something new, this game is for you.

Art and atmosphere enthusiasts: If visual aesthetics, narrative, and music are important to you, Clair Obscur will likely captivate you.

Deep story seekers: If you appreciate character-driven, emotionally, and thematically rich experiences.

Time-intensive players: The game's maps, side quests, and systems require patience to explore; it may be challenging for those looking for a fast-paced, mind-numbingly simple experience.


Cons:

Some technical issues (performance, visual bugs).

There are criticisms regarding exploration, such as "mechanically, it's not enjoyable to explore."


At times, the dramatic story may be considered over-the-top or melodramatic for some players.

If you're looking for a strategy + story + aesthetic RPG, I think it's definitely worth a try.

I think the main reason why I write the review is that after more than half a year, I still have the emotions about this game. It's the music, the visuals, and the story. I want to replay it, but I already finished all the achievements and secrets.

This game is just a light in the horror of the current state of game development. The Sandfall team, thank you, and please keep going!
Think about the best game you played in you career of Gamer, you can know change your mind and think about Clair Obscur: Expedition 33.

In many respects, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a masterpiece. From its deep and challenging turn-based RPG mechanics, to its gorgeous soundtrack that I haven't been able to stop listening to since I started playing. There's something about the world developer Sandfall Interactive has created that just sucks you in. Telling a deeply heartwrenching tale, Clair Obscur is often more than the sum of its parts. Surprising you constantly with new mechanics, new challenges and twists and turns one might not expect. Whilst some of its side missions don't work quite as well as the spine of the experience (looking at you Gestral Games), these are simply side distractions in what is a captivating world filled with brilliant storytelling. One I'd love to see more of one day. Even its turn-based gameplay offers something new to the genre in its parries, dodges and jumps mechanics that task players with the challenge of mastering precise moves in an attempt to block damage or even counterattack for big time damage to your enemies. With so many unique creatures to battle, mastering these mechanics is the real challenge of the game, but also its best features. Beating that difficult boss offers a level of satisfaction that only the likes of Dark Souls can match. 

It's an easy recommendation from me. Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is one of the best turn-based RPGs to come about in years. Special mention as to go to the beautiful soundtrack, which is the best you'll hear all year.

I can't remember ever truly enjoying a turn based RPG, let alone a western one before playing this.
Hell, I can't even name any good games coming out of France/Quebec except older Ubisoft classics before playing this one.

Had a lot of fun with this game, and while I think this is one of the best games of 2025, it is not without some issues that really irked me. 

First the pros: Loved the story and most of the characters. The way the story played out genuinely kept me completely engaged on what would be revealed next. The characters mostly felt genuine and I really came to care for them. Some of the twist reveals were really well done. The graphics are really nice, and just the aesthetic tone of the game through out really helps nail down the feeling of the game as a whole. I think the best part of this game is the soundtrack though. The music is so damn good, and something I can listen to outside of the game. It's rare I want to just hear a game's soundtrack on it's own, but this is one of those.

Cons: The combat after a while with the constant  quick time dodge, parry, jump just got too repetitive. I would have enjoyed it better if that system was for more major attacks from enemies, and not all of them. As someone with ADHD, I would get distracted and take more damage often.  I eventually just got a trainer to auto handle that for me because it overstayed its welcome. Another gripe I had was the movement through the world sometimes felt a bit slow and tedious, especially when on the open map before finding faster ways to move around. The other major gripe I had was not being able to advance conversations during cutscenes. As someone with ADHD and plays with subtitles, I read faster and sometimes just want to move to the next line. The only options available were to watch the cutscene in its entirety or skip it altogether. 

While the gripes keep this game from being my favorite release of 2025, it is still up there in my top 5. I think it's a must play for RPG fans, and people with more patience than my ADHD allows me are sure to not suffer from the same issues I did.

A good game that excels in it’s refreshing approach to turn-based combat and bold narrative. In many ways, this game is very ambitious – so much so that it’s to its own detriment. It tries to do a lot and does a lot well enough so there is a good chance you will find something that will grip you in this game. This game is very close to greatness but it’s just not quite there yet. I recommend you give it a try even if you don’t typically enjoy turn-based games.





[h3][b]Story [SPOILERS][/b][/h3]

[spoiler]The introduction is really good. I found the dialogue in it to be refreshingly earnest – the people you talk to before the expedition felt human. It sets up the melancholic atmosphere of the world and gives both you and the characters hope only to crush it immediately. Even if you perhaps found it predictable, I feel like the true strength of this opening sequence lies in the dialogue that gave a lot of life to Lumiere and its citizens concisely. [/spoiler]

[spoiler]However, the game doesn’t maintain the quality of this intro. For the first few areas you are riding on the thrills of the introduction, getting accustomed to the combat and beginning to ask a lot of questions. Unfortunately, from a narrative perspective all you get to do is ask questions. Whenever you do get an answer, it only ever leaves more questions. A lot of times you can’t even really comprehend what is being talked about, like the nightmares Maelle has for example. This gets exhausting towards the latter part of the middle of the game and while the answers do end up being worth the trouble, it doesn’t change the fact that the flow of information in the story is poorly done.[/spoiler]
 
[spoiler]It’s a brilliant opening sequence followed by an exhausting and confusing middle game that ends with a bombardment of every single question about the world being answered back-to-back in a never-ending sequence of climactic cutscenes and battles. It’s a great story but it should have been executed better.[/spoiler]




[h3][b]Combat[/b][/h3]

Parrying and dodging is a great addition that makes battles much more engaging compared to traditional turn-based combat. Focus is on the parry as dodging ends up being a more niche option. You can build around your dodge but you do lose out on a lot if you don’t parry, so you’re really encouraged to parry. Regardless, dodging is a nice option to have – you can make it easier for yourself and take less risk.

Nevertheless, the limitless potential of parrying is what really makes the combat stand out. You can technically win every battle if you parry every attack, making punching above your weight class a lot of fun.

The excellent sound design also really shines through here – you can at times parry according to audio cues, and the sounds behind parrying give the counter-attacks and the parries themselves a lot of weight making them very satisfying. It plays a big role in keeping the parry of which you will be doing a ton of engaging all the way to the end and it makes up for the faults of the visual presentation.

Another strength of the combat is the pronounced variety between each party members moveset with the addition of a unique gimmick for each one of them. Felt great to try and maximize the potential of some of them, especially Maelle’s Virtuose stance.

Typical turn-based RPG elements are also present – levelling, skill acquisition with skill points, passive abilities through Pictos and Luminas… There’s a lot to minmax which unfortunately sometimes leads to exhaustion. 

To get the most out of your builds you’re encouraged to play around with Pictos, Luminas and weapons. However, you acquire all of those at a fast pace and zones tend to be fairly short with each one having different weaknesses and enemies. All of this is circumvented if you spend time doing optional stuff because you’ll likely be able to get through on raw strength anyway. Similar feelings arise when a new party member joins and you have to learn how to play with their unique ability. It can be overwhelming to keep your build up to date considering how short of a time you get to enjoy it before you are presented with a lot more options.





 
[h3][b]Presentation[/b][/h3]

Visual presentation is what I found to be this games biggest fault. I personally didn’t enjoy the artstyle much but that is a subjective matter. What I’m referring to is the incredibly busy visuals present no matter what you’re doing in the game. The art direction is at fault here. Even if you don’t resonate with the artstyle itself, it’s certainly possible to appreciate it – which is something that was made very difficult as a consequence of poor design choices. 

Your screen is almost always full of particle effects and busy backgrounds. An example of why this isn’t executed well is when the game shows you a vista. During those moments, I found it so difficult to take in the essence of what it’s trying to show you. There are so many visual motifs ever-present and the areas themselves are so short that you were constantly being shown something new, something more. It’s often times very suffocating to look at this game. There are peaceful visuals in this game but it’s either that or rocks flying, dead bodies, the monolith in the background, enemies roaming… The issue becomes not that they want to have a busy arstyle, it’s that they’ve designed it in a way that makes it really difficult to take any of it in and feels like a blur more than anything.

Battles themselves have the same issue. It’s to the point where sometimes it’s hard to tell what an enemy is even doing since the animation and particle effects make it very difficult to see. Not all party member attacks have this problem but enough do where they’re difficult to visually to take in since you’re doing a quick time event during an elaborate animation that is shown to you through shaky camera work and tons of particle effects.

Another issue with the presentation is how, for lack of a better term, “put-together” this game can be. Easily the best example of this is the platforming mini games on Gestral beaches. They feel so out of place and unsophisticated that it’s very hard to take it seriously. Another example is the little zones you find which only contain a music record. Platforming in general looks very clunky. It takes away from the world a lot when lazy, put-together elements are in it.

I realized right from the opening moments that I was going to love this game. I didn’t even know the characters yet and still found myself drowning in the story. It pulled me in instantly. I wish I could wipe my memories just to experience that first playthrough again. No amount of praise could ever do it justice. It’s one of the finest games I’ve played in years — stunning atmosphere, amazing combat, and flawless presentation. Pure cinema. My personal GOTY without a doubt.

⭐ Clair Obscur: Expedition — GOTY Contender Review ⭐

Clair Obscur: Expedition isn’t just another stylish RPG—it’s a bold artistic statement wrapped in one of the most creative combat systems we’ve seen in years. From the moment you step into its surreal, painterly world, you realize this game is doing something different, something that pushes the entire genre forward.

🎨 A Visual Masterpiece

The game blends impressionist art with modern rendering in a way that feels alive. Every environment looks like a moving painting, and every moment is visually breathtaking. It’s not just pretty—it’s unforgettable. This level of artistic identity alone makes it stand out from every other release this year.

I remember I tried out this game, because from what I'd heard kinda reminded me of BG3, and well I soon learned otherwise...

This game is very good and I understand why people liked the game so much, listed below is a segmented review I have of the game.

Art style: Look at trailers and pictures to get the idea but the art style is very majestic and unlike anything I've seen before. I really enjoyed getting to see such a beautiful world as you progress through the story, with this comes the great design of enemies/bosses which always just look so cool to look at.

Music: The music in this game is fabulous because if not only plays great music, but uses it incredibly well. I mean that all the soundtracks fit perfectly to elevate the mood of wherever you are in a game to the next level. It's very rare to see a game that can not only create a masterful soundtrack but nail it on the timing.

Battles: I don't dislike turn-based combat but not necessarily enjoy it either. However I love the combat system where you can learn smart combinations from a wide varity of options and skills the game teaches. Or you can be like me and not think that hard and spend a long time learning how to parry attacks.

Story: I cannot talk much about the story without spoiling but I will say this is one of the greatest stories I have ever experienced, and made me left thinking. The game does a great job of tying together close connections and details with characters with very well done cutscenes. It felt to me like I was watching a theatrical production for most of the game, which I really enjoyed. Here is the premise to understand the start without spoilers: Every year a figure called the Paintress lowers a number on a monolith in the distance, everyone who is that age dies. For awhile now Expeditions go out the year before they know they are going to die to attempt to destroy the Paintress, all have failed.
The game takes this premise and expands on it immensely, making for a story worth the hype- with many twists and turns to keep you engaged. 

My Con- Throughout the story there are many extra areas and side quests. I feel like these need a rework. Some quests are thrown in as fillers with some helpful rewards but don't exactly match the urgency of needing to complete your quest. Some quests have some really great lore and information but these aren't always obvious that they should be done. Others are just off the beaten path. I wish some of these quests that are really good for story were pointed to more clearly, or impropriated into the main story in some fashion. Because it feels a bit weird going through the main story and then picking up the story bits.

Overall: Expedition 33 is a masterpiece and a must-play for people who like to be immersed in an incredible story (and have the patience to see it through)

➤ Genre:
Turn-based RPG / Stylish Combat

➤ Pros:

Stunning visual effects and stylish turn-based combat

Real-time action system that smartly fixes the late-game sluggishness typical of turn-based RPGs

Backgrounds, objects, characters, and creatures all look like pieces of art

French artistic sensibility shines through every part of the game

Cutscenes and cinematic transitions are breathtakingly beautiful

Exceptional soundtrack, with “une vie à t’aimer” being an absolute standout


➤ Overall:
This game is not something you can simply call “just a game.” The gorgeous effects, stylish turn-based combat, and the brilliantly integrated real-time action system create an amazing experience on their own. But what struck me the most was how clearly the developers feel like true artists. The environments, objects, characters, creatures, and every cinematic moment are so artistic that I constantly found myself stopping to admire them. This game perfectly shows why France is known as a nation of artists—sometimes the visuals were so dazzlingly beautiful that I was literally stunned.

The music is just as incredible. Every track is great, but “une vie à t’aimer” is on another level. In the boss fight where the calm classical piece transitions into that song, the screen fades to black, petals blossom, and the melody shifts into electric guitar—no matter how many times I watch it, I get chills. The harmony between the classical female vocal and the modern male vocal always gives me goosebumps.

This isn’t just a game. It’s a piece of art.

Fantastic art evokes emotions; it frees your mind to wonder, to contemplate, to think, and Clair Obscure delivers that. Clair Obscur is French for light-dark; a painting technique that uses color contrasting to convey depth or enhance the dramatization of a subject matter. E33 embraces the essence of Clair Obscure, the contrasts between the gorgeous and the gruesome; it explores and navigates themes like grief, love, and existence.

The narrative is an absolute delight. Its captivating themes are heavy yet never feel overbearing. The characters are written with so much love and attention, brought to life by incredible VOs. The story itself is very unique and impossible to predict, but I will leave it at that.

The Music, oh maaan, I mean... simply speaking I lack the fluancy to describe how amazing it is... The emotions it evokes, the scenes it enhances, even the ambient and effects sound design, oh god, it is so freaking good. 

The graphical art direction left me in awe constantly. I legitimately couldn't close the game; even when I was AFK, the eye candy was real. The animations were clean and satisfying and had some heft to them. Together with the aforementioned sound design, moment-to-moment gameplay just felt great.

The gameplay pulled me in quickly. The turn-based combat felt intuitive from the start, and the surrounding systems; weapons, passives, lumina, pictos, made experimenting feel rewarding without being overwhelming. The active combat moments were a highlight too; landing a perfect parry and following up with a counterattack stayed consistently satisfying.

Finally, the cohesion between the multi-disciplinary art forms comes together so well, enhancing each other and creating a believable world you really want to immerse yourself in without ever wanting to leave.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is easily one of the most stunning gaming experiences I’ve played. I ended up 100% completing it because I simply couldn’t stop playing until I had explored every corner of the world it had to offer. 
The story and characters pulled me in from the very beginning and by the end I was genuinely attached to them. It’s rare to find a narrative this moving, told with such care. 
The world is hauntingly beautiful and the music is phenomenal and elevates every moment. The combat is fluid, stylish, and deeply satisfying. Every encounter feels meaningful and expertly crafted. 
From start to finish, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 delivers an unforgettable experience. It’s visually mesmerising and emotionally gripping. An absolute must-play.

I’ve played so many games, so many masterpieces and classics, I never thought a 2025 game could ever make it on my top 10 list, but here we are.

You absolutely need to play this game.

Heart gripping storytelling with stunning visuals. Engaging gameplay for both the casual and the min-maxer. Breathtaking audio design. Varied build variety rewarded through unique pictos and luminas. All packaged into Unreal engine without murdering your frames. A satisfying post-game for the 100%-er and a more focused mian story for those who just want to expereince it. A definite contender for game of the year.

The only part of the game i did not enjoy was hitting max level, but it only took a few hours to get through.

The world is gorgeous and surreal and the soundtrack + voice acting help make the atmosphere really immersive. The story is heavy, dealing with themes like grief and purpose, but it’s powerful and memorable. It’s a super impressive game for a small studio and one of the standout RPGs of the year. If you like emotional stories, stylish worlds, and strategic combat, Expedition 33 is absolutely worth playing!
Already played this game 1 and half time on Xbox gamepass, bought just for the love of it. Absolute masterpiece, absolute cinema. Infinity/10. A must buy.

I barely ever write reviews for games I played. But this game is the reason I will now...

I am going to repeat words many already have said. This game is a masterpiece in every meaning of that. In the world of recycled ideas, endless sequels of the same recycled ideas which are just identical as the previous 3 entries (yes Ubisoft I am looking at you rn). In the world where game developers do not respect the players' intelligence and spoon-feed the story as if players were 5 years old. And finally in the world where games are created not from pure passion but from will to maximize the profit. In this world, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is THE game that shatters all these stereotypes. This is not even the game, this is a masterpiece which combines multiple layers of art in a beautiful label.

Let me break down every aspect of gameplay to express how incredible this game is:

- Music - Imagine the best film songs you've ever heard; the level of Hans Zimmer, John Williams, or Ramin Djawaldi. Now imagine over 8 hours of soundtrack with the similar level of mastery, every inch of which is so well tailored to the context, the scenes and the characters. Songs which stay with you long after the game ends.

- Sound Design - Not only the music, but also the Sound Design is brilliant. If you are able to parry boss's attacks blindfolded basing it only on the sounds you hear, that means something, and sometimes when I wasn't able to parry some attacks based on the visual aspect, sound was the most helpful factor here. 
Also every location has an amazing ambient which together with music and breathtaking visuals creates a real work-of-art.

- Story and Narrative - I won't spoil anything don't worry, but... the depth of the narrative, the lack of understanding, the emotional build-up, the multi-layeredness of the characters... I have never seen anything like that in any game before. This is the first media that made me cry multiple times in a single playthrough... I almost never cry watching movies or playing computer games; but this damn game broke me. 
I have always hated games which included team management and the main story was spread between multiple characters. I played Baldurs Gate 3 and it didn't attract me as much, even though I deeply understand the hype and value the game (I hope to finish it in the future though :D). Here this hasn't bothered me even for a single second and was perfectly connected to the plot. I haven't felt disrupted for a single moment and was able to ignore my indifference to team management because of how well it was done.

- Gameplay and combat - This is a very interesting concept. It is like the mixture of JRPG, Soulslike, and turn-based combat, but done better in every aspect. This reinvention of traditional JRPG which again was not my cup of tea (I haven't tried Final Fantasy yet so might check it out now) worked perfectly executed. The need of the player being forced to actively participate in combat was the factor that made each fight exciting, and rewarding (especially if you finally learn the attacks of the boss and are able to perfectly parry each one of them). Even if you thought the turn-based combat to be boring, you might be pleasantly surprised when trying out the Expedition 33. 

- Voice acting - Finally the voice acting. If not the wonderful performances of Jeniffer English, Ben Starr or Charlie Cox, this game would not hit as hard as it does. Their skill to paint the characters in so clear and extraordinary way added a cherry on the top and again, I haven't heard another voice acting on a similar level for a while now.

This game is going to be spoken about in a 10, 15, or 20 years from now as a masterpiece; a symbol of what gaming may be in the times of lazy reuse of assets and profit-focused corporations. I genuinely hope for it to win GOTY and I am looking forward for whatever Sandfall Interactive does next. 

For those who come after...

Nothing short of a masterpiece.

The OST is to die for. Over eight hours of atmospheric, immersive music with clear French influences. It elevates every cutscene and every battle (Rain from the Ground is an absolute bop).

Then there’s the story, which is an emotional gut punch in the best possible way. It will make you cry more than once.

It has been a long time since I’ve found a turn-based game that truly breaks out of the mold, but Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 managed to remind me why I fell in love with the genre in the first place. This isn’t just another stylish RPG—it’s an experience that pulls you in with its haunting atmosphere, emotional storytelling, and a world that feels both surreal and painfully human.

What struck me first was how effortlessly the game blends its narrative with gameplay. Every encounter feels intentional, every choice feels heavy, and every moment pushes you further into a story filled with tension, melancholy, hope, and dread all at once. It’s rare for a turn-based title to deliver such a raw mix of emotions, but Expedition 33 does it with confidence.

The music is another standout element. Not simply background noise, it guides the story—elevating quiet moments into something memorable and turning battles into cinematic, pulse-pounding events. The soundtrack aligns so perfectly with the tone of the world that it almost becomes a character of its own.

Combat is where the game truly goes “out of the box.” It reimagines the turn-based formula with a sense of urgency and rhythm, balancing strategy with real-time input in a way that feels fresh without abandoning the roots of the genre. Each battle is a showcase of creativity, blending visual flair with mechanical depth.

With its breathtaking art direction, finely crafted characters, and worldbuilding that lingers in your mind long after you stop playing, Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 feels like one of those rare titles that defines a gaming year. If someone told me this was their personal Game of the Year, I wouldn’t hesitate for a second—I’d probably say the same.

If you’ve been waiting for a turn-based game that dares to be different, deeper, and more emotionally resonant than the rest, this is the one that stands above the crowd.

negative.review:
As much as I loved it for most of my playtime and was genuinely happy to have found a game that has ultimately bringing a lot of joy to my life, I cannot in good faith recommend it to others based on the twist the story takes later in the game. It genuinely ruined the game for me.

The story subverts itself in the worst way possible, throwing most everything that happens for the first 70% out the window. Characters, motivations, even the "central" message of the game (advertising included) get thrown out the window to suddenly turn the story into a completely new story with new characters. People we have come to love due to excellent writing and great characterisation suddenly turn into lobotomised yes-men who don't seem to care about the "twist" the story has taken.

Either of these stories would be great on their own, but the jarring shift in goals and motivations left me genuinely angry. The ending makes this even worse as the seemingly "good" ending (at least the developers seem to think so) is the one where you finally flush the half-dead remains of the first part of the story down the toilet and just focus on the latter part.

Having played the game the line "For those who come after" which is heard often for the first part and seen in marketing is almost false advertising in what the story wants to convey.

This is more of a [b][u]Neutral[/u][/b] recommendation since steam does not have these. And I do not want to give a thumbs up for the following reasons.

The game is OVER hyped. 

I don't know if it's because of "indie company" creating an AAA game, which is true, or I am missing something in this whole game.
I finishing the game on the recommended difficulty and completing most of the side content but I’m feeling conflicted.

To give credits where its due, yes, the visuals and the music is top notch as everyone is yelling. The environments are beautiful, and the soundtrack melancholic, I could describe it like a NieR game.
Another highlight is the passive system of pictos, but I will talk about it later.

And thats it. Thats the good parts of the game. 

The story is mediocre.
Up untill Act 3 it doesn't explain ANYTHING and you constantly have more questions than answers and apparently even the characters do not care.
Like, after Verso joins the expedition instead of bombaring him with questions about everything they wanna know and basically get his knowledge, they ask him some basic stuff and thats it we are friends now...
Unfortunatelly the game did not manage me to care about a single character. I think the writing was all over the place. It started REALLY strong in the prologue, where you are in Lumiere and just witnessing the Gomage, and then you have to go to the expedition. It was really depressing and messed up and you basically go there to make things easier "for those who come after". you are not supposed to survive.
but all of a sudden it got silly. there was a part with a funny huge guy which was a plot device for exploration and all the seriousness of the prologue was gone. the immersion was gone.

The characters were uninsparing,
As I said they did not care, they had like a main goal but thats it, no personality, no nothing.
They didn't even had the mainstream archetypes, like a hothead brute or at least a girl boss, everyone was as bland as the other.
For some reason the game had a social bond mechanic.. ????. which again didn't make sence in this game. they tried to copy it from the ATLUS games but failed miserably. It feels unnecessary: you can level every bond without limits or choices, and the rewards ? a little stronger attack in the combat.

The combat was meh.
It's really cool to have each member of the party having a completely different set of moves and abilites and not the typical: this character has fire dmg, this is the healer, this is the melee, so very nice combat choices, BUT the actual combat was stale. 
You could not change characters mid fight and you did not have to exploit the enemies weaknesses because you don't earn anything like an extra turn.
There is a parry and a dodge mechanic, pretty unique to this type of games, a welcome one but it got tiresome pretty fast. 
Because of these mechanics, there is not a block stance where you boost your defence in your round to survive a strong attack and instead you have to rely on your timing and reflexes. If you miss the timing of a strong attack you are instantly dead btw.
You basically have to stay alive with parries and keep damaging the enemy untill its dead. Minimal strategy.
The passives i mentioned earlier were actually a huge W mechanic. Bassically you can have as many passives as you can afford. Very cool.

The exploration it was ok
Pretty straight forward and linear. Most of the times the things you find are underwelming but at least there was a "reward" for exploring outside of the main path. 
Another thing that done poorly was : you did not know if an enemy was strong or weak before fighting it. There was a "danger" promt outside of some places but not in the enemies. So you can not tell if you can beat an enemy before fighting it. And by that i mean if the enemy was strong you would die one hit, no second chance.

Lastly the voice acting.
The voice acting itself is solid. The actors put genuine emotion into their lines, but the dialogue and writing was limiting the impact of their performances. They do the best they can with what they are given.

Do not get me wrong this is a good game, but it didn’t live up to the overwhelming praise it has received from many players. 
In a more competitive year I believe it could not win GOTY.

I honestly feel like I am crazy for not enjoying this supposedly "game of the decade". I want to love this game, and I was sure I would, yet somehow this game managed to bore and disappoint me. I love story driven game. I love turn based RPG. I love parrying. But this game made me realize that just because the two things are good, doesn't make it a good idea to smush them together. It reminds me of that one Family Guy meme with Noah saying "What the hell is this?" to a child product of an elephant and a penguin.

The long wind up of some of the attacks to bait your parry/dodge drove me crazy. It's almost impossible to tell what's the correct timing for them, unless you memorize each of these attacks. The lack of camera angle freedom means that some attacks does not telegraph well which "phase" it's in at all. Also your character is locked to one place, so that stripped away any decision making ability you can have in a normal dodge/parry fighting game and turned the whole system into a glorified QTE. Even if you decide to ignore the mechanic and just focus on the turn based strategy part, you still have to sit through this slow ass animation every turn. It's excruciating.

Speaking of strategy, there is no strategy. I quickly realized this when I ran into a miniboss way over my level that can one shot my characters, but was able to win on the second or third try anyway thanks to well timed parries/dodges. What's the point of building for anything else if your characters are able to be impervious to all damage? Just optimize for big damage and git gud at dodging. Somehow they made the QTE the most powerful ability you can have in a turn based game. I am not against dodging but I'd rather take a 5% chance dodge/counter armor over this mechanic.

That being said, the world is beautifully crafted. The story is intriguing - the prologue was a super strong opening. It even managed to make me re-examine and look back at my relationships with some of the people around me and that's really something. The music was haunting. But all that couldn't save this game from boring gameplay. Maybe I will revisit the game at a future time, but right now it's a pass from me.

[h1]"For those that come after"[/h1] 
I've never seen a game undermine it's main theme so heavily by claiming to be looking forward to a brighter future whilst the story and it's characters are obsessively stagnating in the past. 

There is also no character development at all really, each character is the same as they were when they started. They never really look at their grief or loss any different than when it all started. At best they exchange witty banter every once in awhile and might share "dark secrets" of their past. 

That is not even mentioning the pace of the game, most of the story takes places at the beginning and end of each Act. So there are large gaps where they are hoping vague information will be enough to carry you forward through the story. With the 3rd Act giving you almost too much information to the point it makes it hard even want to progress to the end because the motivations moving the plot forward come off childish and makes the story feel like unnecessary padding.

[h1]Combat[/h1]

I get why people like the combat but feels at odds with itself as well. There is a awesome and tight strategy system here but the bosses never really ask you to deviate and it can be easily undermined by the action combat that comes during the opponents turn by parrying well. These action elements feel too strong and aren't situational enough to be that interesting. Sure, the timing changes but the mobs in the area also clue you in on the sort of timings and moves you will be dealing with so by the time you're at the boss you're not really learning all that much. I just wish there was more incentive to change my play and that the opponent's turn didn't take focus over the strategic elements of the player turn as it feels like what you do during the opponent's turn matter so much more.

[h1]The Positives[/h1]

[h2]Music[/h2]

 The soundtrack for this game is amazing. Ranging from electronic drum beats to grand operatic orchestrations. I would definitely recommend giving the soundtrack a listen. I would be shocked if there is not at least one track you enjoy.
 
[h2]Visuals[/h2]

The visuals in this game are nothing short of stunning. The atmosphere is pitch perfect, the enemy designs are visual unique from anything I've seen and honestly genuinely lack comparison as they truly feel original short of a few areas like a water themed area where the enemies have anchors or underwater mines but that is about. The environments are filled with cool little visual elements even with it being small instanced environments. I would not fault you taking a screenshot from this game and slapping it as your background.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

The experience did not feel cohesive and there are some really cool ideas there to be sure so I can understand how some people can enjoy this game but I can't personally recommend it as the sum of it's part did not work for me personally. However, if you feel you can overlook it's flaws and embrace the canvas then I would say go for it.

I would say that this should have been a movie, but that would have just made the story issues more obvious. The first several hours of “gameplay” are mostly taken up by cutscenes. The first combat encounter is a cutscene. Over and over, things that could have been barks or environmental storytelling, are cutscenes.

The realtime parry/dodge element ranges between tolerable to insufferable depending on the enemy. It often intentionally mimics soulslikes, where there’s a long wind-up animation for an attack with multiple fake-out movements. If you’ve seen the “how fromsoft makes boss attacks” meme, at least a third of the enemies move like that, and since it’s otherwise turn-based there’s nothing for you to actually do while waiting on it. It wastes a lot of time and adds nothing but mild boredom. The majority of the real-world runtime of a lot of fights is waiting on these animations, and the further into the game you get the more time is wasted on these animations. Thus, the combat gets worse and more boring with every new enemy type.

If you’ve ever played a rhythm game like DDR or beat saber up to the highest difficulty for a song, and then tried to play the same song at the lowest difficulty, that’s essentially what the parry mechanic feels like.

The central conceit of the plot relies on concealing pivotal information and pretending that that is a moral quandary. If the painted people are sentient then they should be kept alive, and if they are not then the canvas must be destroyed. There is no grayness or ambiguity, but the game very much wants to pretend there is by refusing to disclose whether they are sentient or not and giving conflicting information.

LOWER THE DODGE/PARRYING TIMINGS ASAP! 
IF PLAYERS WANT CHALLENGING TIMINGS, THEY DON‘T CHOOSE STORY MODE!

[h1] Not the generational game it was made out to be [/h1]

Expedition 33 is a great game and it deserves game of the year. However, this isnt the revolutionary experience that previous game of the years have provided me with. It’s clear that those calling it groundbreaking have never played any other JRPG in their life.

[h3]Parrying doesn't make turn-based combat better[/h3]

While the parry mechanic is initially engaging, the enemies' extremely limited move sets, make them very predictable after a few turns. It doesn’t hold the long-term appeal of turn-based games that emphasize optimizing each action and exploiting weaknesses. In Expedition 33, I never had to think about my turns, sticking to the same handful of moves for the entire game: Verso slowly builds up Perfection, Lune spams lightning dance, Maelle spams op moves. 

[h3]The levels are poorly designed[/h3] 

Very linear with a few branching paths that lead to trivial rewards. I'm just exploring these visual spectacles on auto pilot. It reminded me of the terrible level design in God of War. The overworld also needs to let players track what they've done.

[h3]The party is so uninteresting.[/h3]

We get some funny interactions here and there but their individual relationships are so shallow and under developed. Characters like Monoco and Sciel are so forgettable and won't leave a lasting impression like other great JRPG party members.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

I'd like to reiterate that this is a well-crafted game with solid music and story. I just wanted to point out and criticize a few of the overhyped aspects. That said, it’s far from unique, and I couldn’t help but think, 'Really? This is the game of the year everyone’s been hyping so much?'
