Having gamed on a PC for most of my life, I find this game a bit bland for my taste. I can see how people that used to play FFX etc on PS2 see it as a polished version of what they used to play as kids, but I just can't seem to get immersed in it.

I've tried so much to like it, but I get bored and cannot come to terms with the limited gameplay, even though there's so much customization with different weapons, skills and attribute combinations.

The game world lacks soul, even though everybody says that there's a very engaging main story with plot twists, which I cannot find the courage to follow because of the boring gameplay.

I used to love old JRPGS on SNES and PSX, but there was the perceived freedom that you were in an open world. This game just throws you in a PS2-like linear minimap that you have to navigate and inevitably come across a minimap boss that looks like it's come from the Dark Souls series.

Anyway, I get the nostalgia some people may feel playing this game, but I just can't recommend it to anyone remotely interested in a game world that actually feels alive and your meaningful interaction with it.

Still terribly optimized for AMD, even mods that are supposed to fix the game due to the crappy engine don't help much. OptiScaler doesn't really help as well. 

It's a shame because the story, combat and characters so far are just simply amazing and I can't wait to, eventually, finish this game. But playing the game for roughly 15 minutes before it inevitably crashes every single time is hardly an enjoyable experience. 

Please, Sandfall, it's high time you guys properly optimize this game for AMD setups.

Damn, I really wanted to like this game. The storytelling in the first two hours was fantastic, but then the gameplay took over. It’s basically just quick-time events, except you never know when to press the buttons. You’re forced to learn through trial and error. The enemy animations are hard to read, and their attacks feel completely random. On top of that, the world feels empty. Sometimes it looks inviting, but your curiosity is never rewarded. I really don't get the hype.

I really liked a lot of parts of this game. However, the parts I disliked (the story) have such glaring issues, it's hard for me to like the rest of the game. I loved the music, the art direction, the characters, the dialogue is good but the story is so unsatisfying and left such a sour taste in my mouth it's impossible for me to say I liked the game when all is said and done. Maybe everyone should play it to decide for themselves but to say this story is masterpiece is ridiculous. There are so many plot holes idk how anyone could glaze it to this degree, at least be honest. The combat is unique but shallow and repetitive. I was so disinterested by the time I got to endgame I was just ready to move on.

This game tricks you into thinking it’s great, when in reality it’s mediocre at best.
It feels like it was made with free assets, and the facial animations are honestly terrible.
The music is fine, but it’s basically the same tune remixed ten different ways, so it gets old fast.
The parry/dodge mechanics are new for a JRPG-style combat system, but they end up feeling pointless. Sure, the timings are made to screw you over at first, but after a dozen fights you’ll barely take any damage, so what’s the point?
I really don’t get why so many people praise it. It’s not bad, but it’s nowhere near a masterpiece.

I would not pay for this game.

Main story = 2/5
Side stories = 2/5
Gameplay = 3/5
Voice acting = 4/5
Dialog = 2/5
Combat = 1/5
Graphics = 5/5

Special note: I'm glad so many people like this game but I can't help but wonder if it's the core gameplay that they love or just the aesthetic. This game feels like it was made by a creative mind that simply refused to compromise their creativity for any other improvements that make this a entertaining video game. The main story is linear. The side stories are inconsequential. The enemies are somewhat-mindless constructs existing at the behest of some greater mysterious evil. The only driving force for continued play is the desire to unearth the ever-growing stack of mysteries dumped at your feet. The story itself has some gaping nonsensical loop holes while the combat breaks down into whether you're good at quick-time events, which in turn makes any strategic choices involving your party & their respective upgrades completely pointless. Maybe the ending made it all somehow worth it but as you can guess, I never bothered getting that far due to boredom.

Dodge/parry QTE combat mechanic in a melancholic story wrapper.
Interesting art-style but disliking the core mechanics and tone it was not compelling enough for me to continue playing.

One-button game. 

Have completed Act 1. The story is good, or have one curious, the characters are great, the music is good, and the graphics are nice (the faces are amazing). The atmosphere and environment is like a children adventure fantasy movie from 80's 90's like Labyrinth, Dark Crystal, Mio in the Land of Faraway, Neverending Story - with a high dose of Studio Gibli inspiration. 

I'm on the fence and would vote neutral if possible, but since it has "overwhelmingly positive" here on steam and won goty, I don't feel bad voting no. After all, if a friend asked me if it was worth playing I would say "nah, not really". 

So what's bad?
The actual gameplay, what makes a game a game. It's basically a One-Button-Game. 
It LOOKS on the surface that there's a lot of tactics and variations involving the gameplay, but those really don't matter much. You attack using the tactic part, then you click the one-button at the right time, trial and error to when that time is, most attacks are not intuitive to when the right time is (which I believe is on purpose since it's 95% of gameplay and 100% of win relevance).  
If you are great at clicking the button no other tactics matter because you are immortal. 
If you suck at clicking the button no other tactics matter because you will die. (you can cheat and put it on easiest, that makes you basically immortal, but it's still a one button game.) 
There is Some range that fits your one button click skill and the enemies power to a degree that using the right tactic actually matter that, that if you failed to do enough damage to your tactics you'd die because of what you lack in clicking-one-button skill, and win with right tactics. But those are quite few - and counting all enemies and bosses, it's basically just a one button game. 

The gameplay aspect feels like a chore to progress the story.  It's not kicking up adrenaline, and you don't even get the "oh yeah fuck you" when you finally beat a difficult enemy encounter, it's more like getting out of an overcrowded subway train - you don't jump and shout "hell yeay I did it!" you grimly think "eww, thank god that's over". 

I'll hopefully finish this game, to enjoy the full story, but I won't enjoy the game part of the game. So no, I can not recommend this game.

edit: finished it now, on immortal/story mode, and my view still stands. If the question was "Do you recommend the story?", or even as a piece of art, the answer would be yes. But the gameplay is too lacking and unenjoyable to recommend it as a game.

Sadly, not for me.  This is a ...beautiful...game, and I am really interested in the story.  However, it is now clear after some play time that this was a game designed for a console controller.  As an old fuddy-duddy chained to my mouse and keyboard I thought I would make a valiant attempt.  But, I am still trying to hit the space bar and the Q button in time with my attacker's moves and failing badly.  It says "turn based" but really they are just strategic combat pauses  so you can choose your next action.  Me and my arthritis just don't do button mashing like that.  I'm sure you CAN play on mouse/keyboard, but do not recommend.  Disappointed, but still a lovely, lovely game.

There is a bug that causes your inputs to sometimes not register on the PC version. It has been documented for over six months but is still confirmed to persist. This is the kind of game where a single dropped input will lead you to a Game Over in later stages of the game. Save yourself the headache.

Incredible game. Great story. Too broken to recommend.

I really want to like this game and I do, BUT the performance is so bad. We the consumer should not need to mod the game to make it play better.
When I finish the game or an update fixes the performance issues then I'll update my review.

Quicktime events for battle absolutely ruined any momentum this game had. I was invested in the story until I started normal battle, where everything is determined by these split-second learned attacks, and the margin of error is so stupid. My hero is obviously out of range of the attack's box, but the timing is wrong so I get hit anyway. 

Watching tiny pixels on the screen and waiting for them to slow down so you can be successful in battle is utterly infuriating. I was expecting a turn based RPG with Realtime elements, but this is a turn-based RPG with very annoying, repetitive Quicktime events. 

The game is beautiful, and the first 2 hours you are not shown how annoying battle can be. It's almost exactly the persona 5 battle system, down to the posing, and exaggerated form of the combat menu. 

Lots of screenshake that can't be reduced only turned off. 

Dodging doesn't get easier. Some moves have multiple attacks you need to dodge. Fail too many of them and the battle is over. 

I failed too many times, even after grinding, and I'm returning it. I'm going against the grain on this one. It's beautiful, but with just being persona battle and adding quicktime events, I think it's another cinematic game on rails that's a little full of itself.

Phenomenal soundtrack, stunning visuals and cinematics, brilliant actor performance. The overall length of cinematics would make for a decent movie or two. Why they needed to strap that to the game is a mystery to me.
It captures you from the start with how it looks and sounds, and the setup of the story makes you want to learn more. Then you get the flashy combat, and you're feeling like it all comes along extremely well, and the general feeling is awesome. Until you reach mid-game. By that time you realize you haven't really learned anything substantial about what's going in in the story (and the game intents to keel you in the dark till the last hours), the exploration is boring and empty (you either find audiologs or music you can play at the camp), except for new equipment pieces, which at a certain point of the game become redundant because you've already come up with the most optimal builds for your character, and there is no point in changing anything. Lack of fast travel feels like a way to make the player spend more time in the game traversing, and lack of the minimap feels like the developers not wishing to underline the game's simplistic level design. I only kept playing for the story, which, to be honest, wasn't anything mind-blowing. I did enjoy it, and I feel like it did well in covering the themes it aimed for, but it has many flaws, which I won't discuss to keep the review spoiler-friendly. Most bosses feel poorly designed in terms of the readability of their attacks. You'll often find too many things on the screen, or the enemy flying back and forth frantically, or all at once. While this game is certainly an impressive project for such a small team, and it sets a healthy precedent, it lacks in many ways; however, I believe it can serve as an excellent foundation for something greater to be built upon. To conclude: rather spectacular experience, but hardly the game of the year.
100/10 game, the minigames are ass and whoever made them should feel bad.

I originally played this game on PS5 and completed it. If you have an NVIDIA card, this game is a solid thumbs-up and you should buy it. The story is phenominal and I'm so glad my first impression was on Playstation instead of what I experienced on PC. 

My review is strictly from the POV of someone with an AMD card, specifically a RX 9070 XT.

This game does not have native support for any AMD up-scaling tech. You're left to choose some Intel's up-scaler or UE5's native up-scaler and both are horrible. Inconsistent picture quality and horrible screen tearing, even with a frame cap and V-Sync enabled. The only decent workaround is by using 3rd party software to modify the game files to trick the game into thinking you have an nvidia card and even that didn't yield good results. 

It's a shame the game isn't supported with AMD's tech. I would've loved to play through again and 100% on pc but I'm just not going to keep playing around with the game files to hope it works. I refunded it for now. If they add support for FSR in the future I will re-buy, but for now my recommendation for AMD GPU users is to be aware you will likely have issues. If you can tolerate all the tech issues, the game is an absolute gem.

The game is really interesting and the graphics are beautiful but the controls and fight actions are so god awful I wanted to throw something at the screen half the time I was playing. 80% of the time, the jump button doesn't work when doing an obstacle and the dodge and parry windows are so ridiculously small it's just infuriating. If you like spending hours trying to get super-miniscule timing down, I guess this is your game. If that's not your idea of a good time with a video game, take a pass.
while its a poilished game, unless you really enjoy turn based combat, this is a snooze fest.

Great story, amazing design, frustrating gameplay. In the easiest difficulty (story mode), some enemies still kill with one hit, have a large amount of hp and execute multiple attacks with multiple hits each turn. The parry system is very intransparent. If you fail, you get no hints to indicate whether you acted too early, too late, or with the wrong counter type (dodge/parry/jump). The game teaches you that enemies execute jump attacks, and that to evade you need to jump at the right time. Then the next boss uses a jump attack that needs to be parried instead of jumping. Level design frequently gives you multiple options on where to go, but zero indication which path will lead to interesting side quests, which ones are optional, and which ones advance the story.

The game is great if you're looking for challenging gameplay and a great story, not so great if you just want to relax and experience the story without fighting the same enemies multiple times to learn their attacks, timings and how to counter them.

Mechanics remind me of a souls game, which was torture to learn, yes it felt satisfying to win a battle but the grind to get there is just a pain in the as$ and I just can't be bothered. I've played 4000 hours of warhammer, so its not the complex games that do me in, just mechanics that rely on tiny degrees of accuracy. 

Guess its just not for me and I restarted six months later thinking I'd give it another go and I got to the troubadour and thought I just can't be bothered.

It chugs along while characters and scenery pop in and out of the game. Gustav’s hair changes back and forth from brown to white by the minute and/or scene. Which is incredibly, incredibly sad. Like, I'm actually seriously depressed, but I've lost all interest in the game and I don't think I'll ever return to finish it. I even looked up what comes after, and [spoiler] even knowing how the rest of the plot plays out, and the various endings, I wouldn't have enjoyed it if I had forced myself to continue. [/spoiler]

I forced myself to keep playing because of the hype, and I genuinely wanted to like the game, but no matter how hard I tried, I could only push myself to the beginning of Act 2. The game has one major flaw, and that is how boring it is.

Negative points:

- The gameplay isn’t balanced. Even if you play normally, as long as you know a bit about JRPGs and have some gaming experience, it’s extremely easy to one-shot every mob. But if you increase the difficulty to hard mode, then they start one-shotting you instead. From what I’ve heard, this imbalance gets even worse in the later arcs.

- The parrying and dodging focused system, while fun at the beginning and seemingly very innovative, soon feels like it kills the strategy factor of  turn-based combat and becomes boring rather quickly.

-  The inability to interact much with the environment , the world makes it feel like you’re not actually there, but rather looking at a painting on a wall. Everything in the environment looks like it’s frozen in time. What I mean is that small details like a chair slightly moving in the air could make the immersion much better.


Positive points:

The music and the beginning of the game until you reach the main continent were genuinely very impressive—there’s not much else I can say.

repetitive ops everywhere
"unnatural" human actions, way too intentional for the story

The game is beautifully made, but just not fun for me.
In many cases it is reflex game where you need to parry or die. Just die a few times and get the attack timing down and then win. Use the "wooosh" sound or the camera zoom as a signal for timing. Not that interesting. Walk to the next monster, parry, go to the next monster, parry... 
For me it is just another entry in the "Final-Fantasy-ish" games.

A friend promised me the story is good and now I think I should have just watched a video about the story and be done with it. At this point after 16 hours, the story is just loose ends that make very little sense... It is a lot of playtime for just loose ends. Like a mystery book that makes you read 300 pages and untangle the whole thing in the last 50.

I might continue at some point, but for now I had enough.

I really want to love Exp33. Love the looks, the combat (even tho it's a bit hard) and the story. But actually playing the game turned into a frustrating fight I didn’t sign up for.

I don’t have a standard 16:9 monitor, and this game absolutely hates that. Unable to change Res, Constant UI and scaling issues, problems with window/fullscreen — the list goes on. I spent more time fiddling with settings and trying to fix things than enjoying the game the devs clearly worked hard on.

It’s genuinely fun when it works i guess, but I just got tired of the technical mess. I want other players with larger or non-standard screens to be aware: you might run into the same headache-inducing problems I did. Hopefully the devs can patch this up, because the game deserves better than to be nearly unplayable for some of us.

TLDR;
If you have a standard 16:9 setup - go for it.
If not - wait for fixes.

This is one of those moments where I kind of wish Steam had a bit more nuance than just thumbs up or down. The game is pretty good, but it certainly was not the life-altering, mind-shattering experience that I heard about going into it. If you're the kind of person who normally wouldn't bother with this game were it not for all the hype, then I don't think you're going to be blown away unless you discover a hidden love of this style of RPG that you just didn't know you had.

It has solid (if somewhat unforgiving) turn-based mechanics. And the visuals are nice, but sort of in the way that I expect this level of fantasy RPG to have nice visuals, ya know? It ticked the checkbox but I didn't find anything ground-breaking about them. (I actually found some of the cut scenes had much more choppy animation than I would've thought.) But the narrative was not super gripping to me, especially at the rate it was drip-feeding information. I gave it nearly 7hrs before going to watch a lore video for the fuller narrative. The combat was repetitive and I just couldn't see myself putting 40+ hours into this to learn all the details.

[spoiler] At its core, the narrative revolves around a mother's loss of one of her children, the insurmountable grief she experiences, and how her fixation and inability to move past that grief impacts the rest of her family and the world around her. It's pretty somber. That being said, this is not even the first new release I've played THIS YEAR that deals with those specific themes. So I wasn't very wowed or shocked by some of the reveals that I think were pretty huge or hard-hitting for other people. [/spoiler] It's a decent story overall, but I think this stands out a lot more for people who are not used to consuming media with themes of loss, grief, or complex family dynamics. 

If you're the kind of person who generally likes turn-based RPGs and can appreciate having to master some pretty precise timing when it comes to dodges and counters in combat, you'll probably have a good time with this and the story may feel like a nice bonus to an otherwise well-constructed game. But if that level of precision isn't your thing or repetitive combat is grating for you, this probably won't be as fun and your own prior media experiences will determine whether the story makes the game worth it to you or not. Knowing what I know now, I've found that I can't honestly recommend this to most of my friends, but I also don't want to condemn it for just not living up to expectations.
the game needs external mods just to fix graphics on the steam deck default ones are a joke

This games advertise itself as a turn-based JRPG, but it's not. Combat is basically QTE and rythm. The parry and dodge system made every other combat mechanics useless. I tried playing in "story" mode difficulty, but it makes combat trivial and boring too. I finished act 1, but right now I don't know if I'll get the motivation to finish the story.

Just didn't really like what I played. Also some of the animations look a little janky. Probably will try again some time later but the game didn't really hook me, I couldn't really care about what was happening.

Without giving any spoilers, the end of Act 1 is lazy writing and is just relying on a generic trope as motivation for a character. It's lazy writing since the whole point they're on the expedition in the first place is to stop the Paintress disappearing the people. It's nothing but copium to say the ending for that act was needed when there was already a reason for motivation in the game where it could've been handled differently. AT the very least, that should be more of an Act 3/late game type beat. Square Enix handled that a lot better with one of their games. It's not surprising that only 56% of players on Steam have the achievement for getting through the area right after the end of Act 1.

The game itlsef is decent, i can't do any reasonably long gaming session though as it has this awfuk smearing issue that's giving me headaches. Why do UE5 games have this issue that devs seem incapable of fixing? barely make it 5 minutes til my eyes get strained trying to find focus when there's non to be had.

Ultimately "vanilla" is the keyword for me. The characters and voice acting are stellar, yet the gameplay and world/map design really lets it down. It plays it safe and doesn't really innovate or excel anywhere. Would highly recommend throwing it on story difficulty and powering through if you want to see what happens.

The visuals and soundtrack are amazing. The story is great until the 3rd act when the writers do a twist that I think hurts the feel of the game. I absolutely  hate the combat, it relying completely on QTEs  to avoid one hit kills from even the basic mobs really drag the game play down.

I desperately wanted to like this. The story behind its development, the aesthetics, the concept, all great.

But I find the combat fairly awful. I think I can tolerate action command turn based combat in something like Paper Mario, or Like A Dragon, but in this is felt annoying. 

Weird complaint, but if it had less involved gameplay, I'd probably enjoy it more.

Feel like I'm going crazy... This is the game everyone has been glazing so hard? 

It's not terrible or anything, but it plays like any dozens of mediocre JRPGs (I know it's not Japanese, but that's the style of game). Combat is ok, but the dodging/parry quicktime system undermines any really interesting builds/combos. As long as you dodge, nothing else really matters. Didn't everyone hate quicktime events a few years ago? 

The story is interesting, but the gameplay isn't fun enough to keep me around for the next story beat. I doubt I'll finish this game. It's not terrible, but I wouldn't recommend it.

If you aren't into Quick Time Events (QTE), do not apply. The game is basically Final Fantasy but *literally every single attack and defense* is a QTE. Story and voice acting sure are nice though.

Some folks might be into QTE-fests, but personally refunded due to the tedium.

I'm really enjoying this game, actually. Good acting, beautiful designs, interesting story, satisfying combat, and more. However, I'm giving it a thumbs down because of the lack of a map. I cannot believe this game, inspired by so many digital role-playing games, doesn't include any sort of map, which has existed in this genre forever. It even fits the theme and story. I'm pretty sure these expeditioners would take notes and make maps as they go through these labyrinths, no?

If the game were strictly linear, I wouldn’t have minded, but a good portion of it is about exploration, and you never know if you're going the way that will progress the story and trigger a cutscene, or if you're finding a side path with optional enemies and items, or if you're just circling around aimlessly. The exploration right now is honestly so excruciating, and it feels even worse because I genuinely want to find everything, but without a map I'm having so much difficulty. Sometimes I just prefer to move forward because I have no idea if I've missed anything or not.

I wish steam had a neutral option. Yes the graphics, music and voice acting is amazing. But I cannot recommend it. The combat twist is nice, but for me once I figured a combo that worked 99% I never felt the need to change anything all up to act 3 where the game while narrative is urgent, it's clear you are meant to spend the next several hours grinding characters, as the enemies now have multiple combo attacks that instantly one shot your characters. 

Then there is the story. Like others who posted negative reviews, I did not buy the story, Act 1 was a great opening and immersive. Then you go out and meant weird creatures and no one questions why, you aren't told why you fight everything. The characters while having some great moments just don't feel real. Events or new party members join and there is no basic questioning of "Hey how the are you alive?" it's like cool we are mates now have a 33 armband. Then the finale. What a insane rug pull. I feel we often seem to give credence to 'mature' story/themes in games. If this was a movie people would have been pissed off. One of the characters is researcher, something happens that any sane person would probably have a mental breakdown over. But everyone just accepts it. The player is presented new characters in Act 3 which you need to suddenly care about or have some emotional bond but as a player you just feel like you wasted your time as the narrative takes massive shift. This along with the insane difficulty spike in Act 3 just broke the game for me, I turned it down from Normal to Story just so I can finish the game. 

Last thing I didn't see any anyone mention. The enviroments are about 50% too large. You'll spend a majority of your time running. The exploration is extremely linear and you will always know what awards you might get. There are also optional bosses that are insanely hard that you won't know are insanely hard. One some locations show danger sign. 

While I think its overrated, I do want to see what Sandfall does in the future.

This game single-handedly ruined JRPGs for me. There will never be another game as visually stunning, story-driven, or with such a satisfying turn-based parrying system as Expedition 33. Every moment feels handcrafted, every fight perfectly tuned. Nothing will come close to filling the void this game has left behind. So for that very reason, I do not recommend anyone play this game. With that being said, I’ll still be nominating this title for game of the year. 10/10.

Expedition 33 is a good idea marred by a lot of bad choices and execution.

The graphics are ok but there are a lot of problems with how they used UE5. Textures have that same "wet, smooth" look that was common in, say, Bloodborne, but that was 14 years ago and looks a bit bad today. Hair textures get weird fuzziness from the smoothing effects, and this is on higher end PCs. The landscapes are pretty but feel a bit lifeless.

Exploration is mostly corridor based, with a few side paths, but those paths are rarely rewarding outside of minor pickups like cash. The late game opens up exploration a lot, but most of the new areas unlocked are single rooms with just one mini-boss enemy or a fixed camera angle with one item to pick up. I found that it really killed my interest in exploring new areas thinking I would move halfway across the overworld map just to find a minor pickup or a boss with nothing I wanted in a single room. It feels like it's wasting your time.

The characters are mostly good. I really enjoyed them, though the motivation of the male lead vacillates back and forth without clear reason in the very late game and he becomes very exasperationg.

Unfortunately, what kills the game is the story and gameplay.

The story starts out decent, but it's clearly trying to hide a very obvious "twist" in the nature of the world. If you pay any attention... like, at *all*, you will figure it out early. The thrust of the story is clear at first, but changes at the end of Act I to become very much yet another bland and tedious family drama story, much in the same vein as all of the other family dramas masquerading as a different genre, such as all of the Haunting of Hill House spinoffs, Hereditary, the VVitch, Babadook, the Arrival. If you love all of those movies, then this story is probably up your alley. If you tired of family melodrama being the main plot of the story (and no, Star Wars doesn't count, because the family drama was secondary to the main story of overcoming despotism and the hero's journey), then you are going to roll your eyes a lot.

Further, the story completely falls apart in the 3rd act, with the entire act being a single short dungeon with 3 optional side quests, all of which are very short but 1. The rest of the map is just new places you have access to, but without a lot of motivation or reason to go to them. The bigger problem is that the motivation of the male lead starts one way in Act II, and then switches in Act III. It makes sense at the time, but the endings are both two of the most atrocious ass-pulls in writing. The male lead suddenly throws out all of his character development at the end to demand one choice, while the female lead completely forgets the entire moral of the story that she's learning. Both endings are bafflingly stupid, considering they completely ignore the entire story to that point.

Finally, the gameplay is just terrible. It's a turn based JRPG style, but the dev is apparently a Sekiro speedrunner and decided that we should all be Sekiro speedrunners. The dodge and parry mechanic could be really great, but on normal and hard difficulty (which have the SAME window), the window to dodge is about 5 frames and the parry window is about 2. Nexus lists them at .35s and .22s respectively, but it's definitely not. It's tied to frames, as many dodge/parries are, and it's extremely tight. The dev also clearly took too much "Margit" from Elden Ring and decided that nearly every enemy needed a lot of long attack delays and feints and many late game enemies can have up to 6 or 7 attacks on their turn. This isn't Sekiro or Souls where you can watch the enemy freely and then engage, no, you must dodge/parry on your first go or die (so many enemies can one hit kill your character or entire team) and retry the fight. It's the bad version of trial and error game play. It's telling that one of the most popular mods gives a huge dodge/parry window (no, I did not use it, I played the entire game unmodded).

Ultimately, the gameplay becomes incredibly tedious, retrying fights, and then if you get the two leads their best weapon, the game is completely broken at that point and no enemy will get a turn again. It's all or nothing and really lacks good combat compression.

In the end, this game is not a bad game, but it's not anything near the incredibly high praise it has received. In a year with both Silksong and Hades 2, the idea that Expedition 33 could be a game of the year is laughable.

I don’t really understand the extreme hype around this game. At first, I found the setting mystical and intriguing, but the longer I played, the sillier the story became. It feels like a slightly more “mature” Alice in Wonderland, just without the charm.

There’s a lot I could criticize, but I won’t spend time listing every detail. People are different, of course, but to me this game felt silly, childish, and all over the place. On top of that, it’s surprisingly poorly optimized for an Unreal Engine title – be prepared for loud fans and hot hardware.

The characters were really well designed and done - amazing voice acting too.  Visually it's a really cool game, and the story has me intrigued.  

That said, every time I play I find myself getting frustrated and loosing interest.  The battles are my chief complaint.  There's no actual strategy, it's just pressing a button to dodge or parry at the right time.  Normal difficulty was frustrating, and easy is just far too easy.  

10 hours in and I'm calling it quits... really wanted to like this game, but just didn't do it for me.

Insane levels of hype for this game gave me too high expectations, thought I was getting Jesus Christ reincarnated in gaming form, based off other reviews over the past 6 months. Instead I got another turned-based game with that generic UE vibe to it, impossible dogding/parry mechanics.

I'm sure it's good later on, but if I'm getting mad at the combat in the prologue, then it clearly isn't for me.

Not for me.

I see a lot of people loving the story, but at least for the time I’ve been playing, it doesn’t feel special. The biggest issue is that I can’t connect with the characters. Their emotions don’t feel real or consistent with what’s happening. People are dying around them, and two minutes later they’re cracking jokes—it just doesn’t fit. If they don’t give a s***, why should I?

About the enviroment and gameplay, it’s disappointing. The maps are really nice, however, the world feels very linear. The game invite you all the time to go around collecting useless items. Each character has their own set of abilities you can invest time optimizing with specific objects, but ultimately none of that really matters. The only truly important skill is learning enemy attack patterns to dodge. Sure, if you optimize everything you might defeat enemies a bit faster, but the difference is minimal.
The act 2 ending "big" reveal ruined the story for me, if the writers don't care about the expedition itself why would i

Combat calls itself turn based but the single most important aspect, in early game at the very least, are the dodge/parry mechanics, which has absolutely nothing to do with turn based combat.

The visual and narrative design seem amazing and I would have loved to see more of the game but the combat genuinely ruined it for me. I did not have a moment of fun in all of the 7 hours i forced myself to play this. 

Of course that puts me right outside of steams refund window, so money down the drain.
A demo would have been nice, could have spared me the 50 bucks.

Cannot in all honesty recommend this game, unless you love childish drama, pretentiousness dressed up as art, an unlikable starting character, an English localization that just falls flat and a wholly unoptimized game. The hype train has really run off on this one.......

I got past the prologue and could not tolerate to go any further. My impression was that they wanted to have a game that could be considered in the realm of Kojima but from France. Missed the mark by some leagues.

Some details:
- the characters have all kinds of clipping issues in the in-engine cutscenes
- the cutscenes are all grainy and pixelated (pre-rendered ones)
- the characters do not blink enough... I kid you not, they look like freaking monsters because of it.
- performance drops so low in plain exploration scenes. My rig can run games that have higher specs than this no problem, yet this game tanks when just running around..........

Yes, I can say that the style of the game, storyline and characters are all subjective... BUT I do not consider the topic of this being "a small indie team" to factor into any of the above. Also, delivering a game that is not optimized is not okay in todays world. Activision or Microsoft would get ripped apart for delivering such a badly optimized game, but here it is okay?!

Clear thumbs down from me.

I am 50/50 on this game, story is good, game play is good, music is good. The technical aspects and choices of this game are not.

The music is really good, it sets the mood quite well. The story pulls you in and makes you guess at what it going on. The character animations, albeit a little stuttery, the animators did an amazing job expressing emotion on characters faces and it feels like you are watchin real poeple. The blend of 3rd person and JRPG elements is simply awesome. The game battle mechanics are a pleasure to use, are innovative, and don't reinvent the wheel with JRPGs but add interesting elements. I haven't played a JRPG for a long time, this is well done. 

Don't get me wrong this is a good game but it is not great as it is plagued by technical issues, bad optimization and lazy development practices. This could be a great game if it wasn't for the stutters, graphical glitches, and poor technical choices.

I had to find a fix for resolution scaling, the game forces upscaling by default even when you turn off the scaling it still applies it. I had to use a third party fix to run my game at full resolution 5120X2160, I got that fix from here: https://github.com/Lyall/ClairObscurFix . Without it the game would be scaled down to 3820x1440 and no matter what I did I could not set the proper resolution. The use of blur in cutscene backgrounds is a terrible choice. It is distracting and unnatural. 

I have to use both DLSS frame gen and Scaling on a 5090 which is absolute nonsense.
Lazy development practices in the industry think it is ok to rely on AI scaling and frame gen, it is not, optimize your games. Despite this being a good game as far as story, music, and gameplay goes I give it a thumbs down due to the terrible optimization of the game. UE5 is not the shortcut solution that developers think it is, EPIC games conned you into thinking otherwise.  

Not all is lost and there is hope. More and more developers are aware of the sh!t show that is UE5 and how to optimize the engine for their game. Hopefully Sandfall take what the industry has learned in the last few months and optimize this.

Until this is optimized I can not recommend this game outside of top tier systems!

[h1] For Those Who come After [/h1]

As Somebody who plays way too many JRPGs I can tell they put a lot of love and care into making this game. There is quit a bunch to Love about this game but for me they really dropped the ball on 2 of the biggest things that make a JRPG styled game actually good for me. But first let me touch on...


[h2] The Good [/h2]
 
[h3] The Premise [/h3] 
I think the initial set-up to the plot is a super cool an unique idea. Its really lends it self to something a lot of good stories need, a sense of Mystery and a good reason to even head out on the adventure to begin with. I pretty instantly wanted to head out on the adventure and see what the hell was going on for myself, It's a Great initial hook!

[h3] Music [/h3]
Overall the music in this game is pretty solid, nothing stood out as particularly bad or ear grating it did a good job of fitting the zones and scenes. It's not the most amazing OST of all time but there are a few bangers especially in a few of the later boss fights just don't go expecting a Yoko Shimomura or REVO level of soundtrack.
 
[h3]A Game With Post Game Content!?[/h3] 
Ya love to see it! Nothing makes me more sad then finishing an RPGs main story and there's not even a few extra dungeons to explore or further challenges to tackle. Luckily this game has a good chunk of post game dungeons a boss fights to indulge in, That's a major win in my book. Along with a lot of pretty silly mini games and unlockable costumes and rewards this part honestly is what I'd like to see more of in general!

[h2] The Mixed [/h2]

[h3] The Overall Visuals [/h3]
It's been a while since I played a game that had moments where it flops back and forth between being Beautiful and Hideous so often There will be some zones that have such a wide open stunning look to them followed by a zone that's super cluttered and visually messy. The characters in cutscenes also go from looking pretty good to like unfinished animation work depending on what random scene you're in and mixing it with some of the most noticeably bad Lip Sync i've ever seen ina game like this it can be kind of jarring sometimes.

[h3] The Characters [/h3]
I really want to love the party of ever RPG I play but sadly here I really only like about half of them. 2 of them are the most nothing burger party members of all time. I really enjoyed the last 2 party members you get the most and a special round lad. I feel like the game was too short for its own good you can probably finish the Main story in about 25 hours I would have liked for it to be a bit longer  so they could give us some time to do fun things with the party  maybe I would have liked them a bit more than I ended up.

[h2] The Bad [/h2]

This is really what dragged the game down for me ALOT The 2 things if only one of these things let me down maybe it might have saved it for me but the worst part of this game for me had to be...

[h3] The Combat [/h3]
I LOVE, LOVE Good turn based combat I love equipping my team with unique abilities and passives find the most broken gear setup and coming up with my own fun strategy on how to take on any given boss ahead of me!
Well none of that matters at all in this game because there is only 1 way to just beat the whole game with 0 thought PARRYING. you can stop all damage in this game from ever happening and then hit every boss and enemy for massive damage. I think if this game kept its action commands for attacks and removed the parries while adding some more defensive options it could have been ok. I like that every character has their own cool combat style and gimmick it's just kind of sad none of it really matters at all. If you're someone who plays any sort of fighting games or rhythm games this might be the easiest game of all time, on any of the Main story bosses on hard mode I died a total of 0 times the only things that killed me early on were super bosses I shouldn't have been fighting till end game, and within a few attempts I beat most of them.

And the thing that really just pushed the game over the edge for me was...

[h3] The Story [/h3]

I'm not going to go into too much detail here to avoid spoilers, but as someone who was kind of vibing with the game thru the first few acts. That final act was actually one of the most poorly executed final chapters of a game i've played in so long. It Feels extremely rushed and un-finished they just present you with a new lump of information don't proceed to elaborate or explore the idea then end the game.  It really feels like there should have been another 10-20  hours stapled onto this game in the middle and towards the end to actually finish it, but I guess this is what we're left with.

If you Like this game I'm happy I hope more people get into JRPGs because of this game and if you liked this game PLEASE check out other games in the genre, this is but a small bite of a much bigger cake.
In the end people were right it really is a game that will stick with me forever, Just not in the way I was hoping.
